verses.name: On Our Lord 1:1
verses.text: Three Homilies.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:2
verses.text: On Our Lord.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:4
verses.text: Grace has drawn nigh to mouths, once blasphemous, and has made them harps; sounding praise.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:5
verses.text: Therefore let all mouths render praise to Him Who has removed from them blasphemous speech.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:6
verses.text: Glory to Thee Who didst depart from one dwelling to take up thy abode in another! that He might come and make us a dwelling-place for His Sender, the only-begotten departed from [being] with Deity and took up His abode in the Virgin; that by a common manner of birth, though only-begotten, He might become the brother of many.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:7
verses.text: And He departed from Sheol and took up His abode in the Kingdom; that He might seek out a path from Sheol which oppresses all, to the Kingdom which requites all.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:8
verses.text: For our Lord gave His resurrection as a pledge to mortals, that He would remove them from Sheol, which receives the departed without distinction, to the Kingdom which admits the invited with distinction; so that, from [the plan] which makes equal the bodies of all men within it, we may come to [the plan] which distinguishes the works of all men within it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:9
verses.text: This is He Who descended to Sheol and ascended, that from [the place] which corrupts its sojourners, He might bring us to the place which nourishes with its blessings its dwellers; even those dwellers who, with the possessions, the fruits, and the flowers, of this world, that pass away, have crowned and adorned for themselves there, tabernacles that pass not away.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:10
verses.text: That Firstborn Who was begotten according to His nature, was born in another birth that was external to His nature; that we might know that after our natural birth we must have another birth which is outside our nature.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:11
verses.text: For He, since He was spiritual, until He came to the corporeal birth, could not be corporeal; in like manner also the corporeal, unless they are born in another birth, cannot be spiritual.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:12
verses.text: But the Son Whose generation is unsearchable, was born in another generation that may be searched out; that by the one we might learn that His Majesty is without limit, and by the other might be taught that His grace is without measure.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:13
verses.text: For great is His Majesty without measure, Whose first generation cannot be imagined in any of our thoughts.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:14
verses.text: And His grace is abundant without limit, Whose second birth is proclaimed by all mouths.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:16
verses.text: This is He Who was begotten from the Godhead according to His nature, and from manhood not after His nature, and from baptism not after His custom; that we might be begotten from manhood according to our nature, and from Godhead not after our nature, and by the Spirit not after our custom.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:17
verses.text: He then was begotten from the Godhead, He that came to a second birth; in order to bring us to the birth that is discoursed of, even His generation from the Father:—not that it should be searched out, but that it should be believed;—and His birth from the woman, not that it should be despised, but that it should be exalted.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:18
verses.text: Now His death on the cross witnesses to His birth from the woman.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:19
verses.text: For He that died was also born.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:20
verses.text: And the Annunciation of Gabriel declares His generation by the Father, namely [the power of the Highest shall overshadow thee].

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:21
verses.text: If then it was the power of the Highest, it is plain that it was not the seed of mortal man.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:22
verses.text: So then His conception in the womb is bound up with His death on the cross; and His first generation is bound up with the declaration of the Angel; in order that whoso denies His birth may be confuted by His crucifixion, and whoso supposes that His beginning was from Mary, may be admonished that His Godhead is before all; so that whoever has concluded His beginning to be corporeal, [may be proved to err hereby that His issuing forth from the Father is narrated].

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:23
verses.text: The Father begat Him, and through Him created the creatures.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:24
verses.text: Flesh bare Him and through Him slew lusts.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:25
verses.text: Baptism brought him forth, that through Him it might wash away stains.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:26
verses.text: Sheol brought Him forth, that through Him its treasures might be emptied out.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:27
verses.text: He came to us from beside His Father by the way of them that are born:  and by the way of them that die, He went forth to go to His Father; so that by His coming through birth, His advent might be seen; and by His returning through resurrection, His departure might be confirmed.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:29
verses.text: But our Lord was trampled on by Death; and in His turn trod out a way over Death.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:30
verses.text: This is He Who made Himself subject to and endured death of His own will, that He might cast down death against his will.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:31
verses.text: For our Lord bare His cross and went forth according to the will of Death:  but He cried upon the cross and brought forth the dead from within Sheol against the will of Death.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:32
verses.text: For in that very thing by which Death had slain Him [i-e:, the body], in that as armour He bore off the victory over Death.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:33
verses.text: But the Godhead concealed itself in the manhood and fought against Death, Death slew and was slain.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:34
verses.text: Death slew the natural life; and the supernatural life slew Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:35
verses.text: And because Death was not able to devour Him without the body, nor Sheol to swallow Him up without the flesh, He came unto the Virgin, that from thence He might obtain that which should bear Him to Sheol; as from beside the ass they brought for Him the colt whereon He entered Jerusalem, and proclaimed concealing her overthrow and the destruction of her children.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:36
verses.text: With the body then that [was] from the Virgin, He entered Sheol and plundered its storehouses and emptied its treasures.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:37
verses.text: He came then to Eve the Mother of all living.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:38
verses.text: This is the vine whose fence Death laid open by her own hands, and caused her to taste of his fruits.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:39
verses.text: So Eve the Mother of all living became the well-spring of death to all living.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:40
verses.text: But Mary budded forth, a new shoot from Eve the ancient vine; and new life dwelt in her, that when Death should come confidently after his custom to feed upon mortal fruits, the life that is slayer of death might be stored up [therein] against him; that when Death should have swallowed [the fruits] without fear, he might vomit them forth and with them many.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:41
verses.text: For [He Who is] the Medicine of life flew down from heaven, and was mingled in the body, the mortal fruit.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:42
verses.text: And when Death came to feed after his custom, the Life in His turn swallowed up Death.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:43
verses.text: This is the food that hungered to eat its eater.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:44
verses.text: So then, by one fruit which Death swallowed hungrily, he vomited up many lives which he had swallowed greedily.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:45
verses.text: The hunger then which hurried him against one, emptied out his greed which had hurried him against many.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:46
verses.text: Thus Death was diligent to swallow one, but was in haste to set many free.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:47
verses.text: For while One was dying on the cross, many that were buried from within Sheol were coming forth at His cry.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:48
verses.text: This is the fruit that cleft asunder Death who had swallowed it, and brought out from within it the Life in quest of which it was sent.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:49
verses.text: For Sheol hid away all that she had devoured.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:50
verses.text: But through One that was not devoured, all that she had devoured were restored from within her.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:51
verses.text: He, whose stomach is disordered, vomits forth both that which is sweet to him and that which is not sweet.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:52
verses.text: So the stomach of Death was disordered, and as he was vomiting forth the medicine of life which had sickened it, he vomited forth along with it also those lives that had been swallowed by him with pleasure.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:54
verses.text: This is the Son of the carpenter, Who skilfully made His cross a bridge over Sheol that swallows up all, and brought over mankind into the dwelling of life.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:55
verses.text: And because it was through the tree that mankind had fallen into Sheol, so upon the tree they passed over into the dwelling of life.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:56
verses.text: Through the tree then wherein bitterness was tasted, through it also sweetness was tasted; that we might learn of Him that amongst the creatures nothing resists Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:57
verses.text: Glory be to Thee, Who didst lay Thy cross as a bridge over death, that souls might pass over upon it from the dwelling of the dead to the dwelling of life!  5.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:58
verses.text: The Gentiles praise Thee that Thy Word has become a mirror before them, that in it they might see death, secretly swallowing up their lives.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:59
verses.text: But graven images were being adorned by their artificers; and by their adornments were disfiguring their adorners.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:60
verses.text: But Thou didst draw them to Thy cross; and while the beauties of the body were disfigured upon it, the beauties of the mind shone forth upon it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:61
verses.text: Then, as for the Gentiles who used to go after gods which were no gods, He Who was God went after them, and by His words, as by a bridle, turned them from many gods to the One.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:62
verses.text: This is that Mighty One, Whose preaching became a bridle in the jaws of the Gentiles, and led them away from idols to Him that sent Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:63
verses.text: But the dead idols, with their closed mouths, used to feed on the life of their worshippers.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:64
verses.text: On this account Thou didst mingle in their flesh that blood of Thine, by which death was enfeebled and laid low; that the mouths of their devourers might be driven away from their lives.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:65
verses.text: Also because Israel slew Thee and was defiled by Thy blood, that idolatry, that had been engrafted upon him was driven away from him on account of Thy blood.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:66
verses.text: For he was weaned from that heathenism through Thy blood; because that from it, he had never before been weaned.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:68
verses.text: But Israel crucified our Lord, on the plea that verily He was seducing us from the One God.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:69
verses.text: But they themselves used constantly to wander away from the One God through their many idols.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:70
verses.text: While then they imagine they crucify Him Who seduces them from the One God, they are found to be led away by Him from all idols to the One God; to the end that because they did not voluntarily learn of Him that He is God, they might by compulsion learn of Him that He is God; when the good which had accrued to them through Him should accuse them concerning the evil which their hands had done.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:71
verses.text: Thus even though the tongue of the oppressors denied, yet the help with which they were helped convicted them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:72
verses.text: For grace loaded them beyond their power, so that they should be ashamed, while laden with Thy blessings, to deny Thy person.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:73
verses.text: And also Thou didst have mercy on those, whose lives had been made food for dead idols.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:74
verses.text: For the one calf which they made in the desert, pastured on their lives as on grass in the desert.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:75
verses.text: For that idolatry which they had stolen and brought out in their hearts from Egypt, when it was made manifest, slew openly those in whom it was dwelling secretly.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:76
verses.text: For it was like fire concealed in wood, which when it is gendered from within it, burns it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:77
verses.text: For Moses ground to powder the calf and caused them to drink it in the water of ordeal; that by drinking of the calf all those who were living for its worship might die.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:78
verses.text: For the sons of Levi ran upon them, those who ran to [help] Moses and girded on their swords.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:79
verses.text: For the sons of Levi did not know whom they should slay, because those that worshipped were mingled with those that worshipped not.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:80
verses.text: But He, for Whom it was easy to distinguish, distinguished those who were defiled from those who were not defiled; so that the innocent might give thanks that their innocence had not passed [unseen by] the Just One; and the guilty might be convicted that their offence had not escaped [the eye of] the Judge.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:81
verses.text: But the sons of Levi were the open avengers.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:82
verses.text: Accordingly Moses set a mark upon the offenders, that it might be easy for the avengers to avenge.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:83
verses.text: For the draught of the calf entered those in whom the love of the calf was dwelling, and displayed in them a manifest sign, that the drawn sword might rush upon them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:84
verses.text: The congregation therefore which had committed fornication in [the worship of] the calf, he caused to drink of the water of ordeal, that the mark of adulteresses might appear in it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:85
verses.text: From hence was derived that law about women, that they should drink the water of ordeal, that by the mark that came on adulteresses, the congregation might be reminded of its fornication that was in the worship of the calf, and be on its guard with fear against another [fornication]; and remember the former [fornication] with penitence of soul; and that when they were judging their women, if they played the harlot against them, they might condemn themselves, who were playing the harlot against their God.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:87
verses.text: To Thee be glory who by Thy cross hast taken away the heathenism in which both circumcised and uncircumcised were caused to stumble!  To Thee be praise, the medicine of life, Who hast converted all that are baptised, to Him Who is life of all, and Lord of all!  The lost that are found bless Thee; for by the finding of the lost, Thou hast given joy to the angels that are found and were not lost.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:88
verses.text: The uncircumcised praise Thee, for in Thy peace the enmity that was between is swallowed up, for Thou didst receive in Thy flesh the outward sign of circumcision, through which the uncircumcised that were Thine, used to be accounted as not Thine.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:89
verses.text: For Thou didst make as Thy sign the circumcision of the heart; by which the circumcised were made known, that they were not Thine.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:90
verses.text: For Thou didst come to Thine own and Thine own received Thee not; and by this they were made known that they were not Thine.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:91
verses.text: But they to whom Thou didst not come, through Thy mercy cry out after Thee, that Thou wouldst satisfy them with the crumbs which fall from the children's table.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:93
verses.text: God was sent from the Godhead, to come and convict the graven images that they were no gods.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:94
verses.text: And when He took away from them the name of God which decked them out, then appeared the blemishes of their persons.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:95
verses.text: And their blemishes were these;—They have eyes and see not, and ears and hear not.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:96
verses.text: Thy preaching persuaded their many worshippers to change their many gods for the One.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:97
verses.text: For in that Thou didst take away the name of godhead from the idols, worship also along with the name was withdrawn; that, namely, which is bound up with the name; for worship also attends on the Name of God.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:98
verses.text: Because, then, worship also was rendered to the Name, by all the Gentiles, at the last the worshipful Name shall be gathered in entirely to its Lord.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:99
verses.text: Therefore at the last worship, also shall be gathered in completely to its Lord, that it may be fulfilled that all things shall be subjected to Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:100
verses.text: Then, He in His turn shall be subjected to Him Who subjected all things to Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:101
verses.text: So that that Name, rising from degree to degree, shall be bound up with its root.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:102
verses.text: For when all creatures shall be bound by their love to the Son through Whom they were created, and the Son shall be bound by the love of that Father by Whom He was begotten, all creatures shall give thanks at the last to the Son, through Whom they received all blessings; and in Him and with Him they shall give thanks also to His Father, from Whose treasure He distributes all riches to us.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:104
verses.text: Glory be to Thee Who didst clothe Thyself in the body of mortal Adam, and didst make it a fountain of life for all mortals.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:105
verses.text: Thou art He that livest, for Thy slayers were as husbandmen to Thy life, for that they sowed it as wheat in the depth [of the earth], that it may rise and raise up many with it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:106
verses.text: Come, let us make our love the great censer of the community, and offer on it as incense our hymns and our prayers to Him Who made His cross a censer for the Godhead, and offered from it on behalf of us all.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:107
verses.text: He that was above stooped down to those who were beneath, to distribute His treasures to them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:108
verses.text: Accordingly, though the needy drew near to His manhood, yet they used to receive the gift from His Godhead.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:109
verses.text: Therefore He made the body which He put on, the treasurer of His riches, that He, O Lord, might bring them out of Thy storehouse, and distribute them to the needy, the sons of His kindred.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:111
verses.text: Glory be to Him Who received from us that He might give to us; that through that which is ours we might more abundantly receive of that which is His!  Yea through that Mediator, mankind was able to receive life from its helper, as through a Mediator it had received in the beginning death from its slayer.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:112
verses.text: Thou art He Who didst make for Thyself the body as a servant, that through it Thou mightest give to them that desire Thee, all that they desire.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:113
verses.text: Moreover in Thee were made visible the hidden wishes of them that slew [Thee] and buried [Thee]; through this, that Thou clothedst Thyself in a body.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:114
verses.text: For taking occasion by that body of Thine, Thy slayers slew Thee, and were slain by Thee; and taking occasion by Thy body, Thy buriers buried Thee, and were raised up with Thee.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:115
verses.text: That Power Which may not be handled came down and clothed itself in members that may be touched; that the needy may draw near to Him, that in touching His manhood they may discern His Godhead.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:116
verses.text: For that dumb man [whom the Lord healed] with the fingers of the body, discerned that He had approached his ears and touched his tongue; nay, with his fingers that may be touched, he touched Godhead, that may not be touched; when it was loosing the string of his tongue, and opening the clogged doors of his ears.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:117
verses.text: For the Architect of the body and Artificer of the flesh came to him, and with His gentle voice pierced without pain his thickened ears.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:118
verses.text: And his mouth which was closed up, that it could not give birth to a word, gave birth to praise to Him Who made its barrenness fruitful in the birth of words.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:119
verses.text: He, then, Who gave to Adam that he should speak at once without teaching, Himself gave to the dumb that they should speak easily, tongues that are learned with difficulty.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:121
verses.text: Lo, again, another question is made clear:—We enquire in what tongues our Lord gave the power of speaking to the dumb, who from all tongues came unto Him?  And although this be easy to know, yet our soul impels us to that knowledge which is greater than this.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:122
verses.text: That [knowledge] then is, to know that through the Son the first man was made.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:123
verses.text: For in this fact, that through Him speech was given to the dumb, the sons of Adam, we may learn that through Him speech was given to Adam their first father.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:124
verses.text: And here also defective nature was supplied by our Lord.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:125
verses.text: He, then, Who was able to supply the defect of nature,—it is manifest that through Him is established the supplying of nature.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:126
verses.text: But there is no greater defect than this, when a man is born without speech.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:127
verses.text: For since it is in this, in speech, that we excel all the creatures, the defect of it is greater than all [other] defects.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:128
verses.text: He, then, through Whom all this defect was supplied,—it is manifest that through Him all fulness is established.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:129
verses.text: But because through Him the members receive all fulness in the womb secretly, through Him their defect was supplied openly; that we might learn that through Him in the beginning the whole frame was constituted.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:130
verses.text: He spat then on His fingers and placed them in the ears of that deaf man; and He mixed clay of His spittle, and spread it upon the eyes of the blind man; that we might learn that as there was defect in the eyeballs of that man who was blind from his mother's womb, so there was defect in the ears of this [man].

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:131
verses.text: So then, by leaven from the body of Him Who completes, the defect of our formation is supplied.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:132
verses.text: For it was not meet that our Lord should have cut off anything from His body to supply the deficiency of other bodies; but with that which could be taken away from Him, He supplied the deficiency of them that lacked; just as in that which can be eaten, mortals eat Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:133
verses.text: He supplied then the deficiency, and gave life to mortality, that we may know that from the body in which fulness dwelt, the deficiency of them that lacked was supplied; and from the body in which life dwelt, life was given to mortals.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:135
verses.text: Now the Prophets performed all [other] signs; but on no occasion supplied the deficiency of members.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:136
verses.text: But the deficiency of the body was reserved, that it should be supplied through our Lord; that souls might perceive that it is through Him that every deficiency must be supplied.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:137
verses.text: It is meet, then, that the prudent should perceive that He Who supplies the deficiencies of the creatures, is Master of the formative power of the Creator.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:138
verses.text: But when He was upon earth, our Lord gave to the deaf [and dumb], [the power] of hearing and of speaking tongues which they had not learned; that after He had ascended, [men] might understand that He gave to His disciples [the power] of speaking in every tongue.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:140
verses.text: Now the crucifiers supposed when our Lord was dead that His signs had died with Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:141
verses.text: But His signs manifestly continued to live through His disciples; that the murderers might know that the Lord of the signs was living.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:142
verses.text: Beforehand His murderers made trouble, crying out that His disciples had stolen His corpse.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:143
verses.text: But, afterwards, His signs performed through His disciples, filled them with trouble.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:144
verses.text: For His disciples, who were supposed to have stolen the dead corpse, were found to be raising to life the dead corpses of others.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:145
verses.text: But the ungodly were terrified and said;—"His disciples have stolen His body;" that they might be held in contempt when it should be discovered.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:146
verses.text: But the disciples, who [they said] stole the dead body from the living guards, were found to be assailing Death in the name of Him Who was stolen; that [Death] might not steal the life of the living.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:147
verses.text: So then, before He was crucified, He gave the deaf the power of hearing, that after He was crucified, all ears should hear and believe in His resurrection.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:148
verses.text: For beforehand He confirmed our hearing by [the word] of the dumb whose mouth was opened, that it should not doubt concerning the preaching of the Word.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:149
verses.text: Our Redeemer was in every way equipped, that in every way He might rescue us from our captor.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:150
verses.text: For our Lord did not merely clothe Himself in a body, but also arrayed Himself in members and in garments; that through His members and His garments, they that were afflicted with plagues might be encouraged to approach the treasury of healing, that they who were encouraged by His mercy might approach His body and they who were dismayed by His terror might approach His vesture.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:151
verses.text: For with one woman her fear suffered her merely to approach the hem of His raiment; but with another, her love impelled her even to approach His flesh.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:152
verses.text: Now by her who received healing by His garments, those were put to shame who did not receive healing from His words; and by her who kissed His feet, he was rebuked who did not desire to kiss His lips.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:154
verses.text: Now our Lord bestowed great gifts through small means; that He might teach us of what they are deprived who have scorned great things.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:155
verses.text: For if from the hem of His garment, healing like this was secretly stolen, could He not assuredly heal when His word distinctly granted healing?  And if defiled lips were sanctified by kissing His feet, how much more should not pure lips be sanctified by kissing His mouth?  For the sinful woman by her kisses received the grace of His sacred feet, which had come with toil to bring her remission of her sins.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:156
verses.text: She was refreshing the feet of her Healer with oil freely, for freely had He brought her the treasure of healing for her sickness.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:157
verses.text: For it was not for the sake of his stomach that He Who satisfies the hungry was a guest; but for the sake of the sinful woman's repentance He Who justifies sinners made Himself a guest.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:159
verses.text: For it was not for the dainties of the Pharisees that our Lord hungered, but for the tears of the sinful woman He was an hungered.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:160
verses.text: For when He was satisfied and refreshed by the tears for which He hungered, He turned and rebuked him who had bidden Him to the food that passes away, that He might show that it was not for the sake of food for the body that He had become a guest, but for the sake of help to the soul.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:161
verses.text: For it was not for the sake of pleasure that our Lord mingled with gluttonous men and winebibbers, as the Pharisee supposed; but that in their food as mortals He might mingle for them His teaching as the medicine of life.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:162
verses.text: For even as it was in the matter of eating that the Evil One gave his deadly counsel to Adam and his helpmeet, so in the matter of eating the Good Lord gave His life-giving counsel to the sons of Adam.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:163
verses.text: For He was the fisherman Who came down to fish for the lives of the lost.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:164
verses.text: He saw the publicans and harlots rushing into prodigality and drunkenness; and He hastened to spread His nets amongst their places of assembly, that He might capture them from food that fattens bodies, to fasting that fattens souls.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:166
verses.text: Now the Pharisee made great preparations for our Lord in His banquet; and the sinful woman did but little things for Him there.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:167
verses.text: Yet he by his great dainties displayed the smallness of his love to our Lord; but she by her tears displayed the greatness of her love to our Lord.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:168
verses.text: Thus he that had invited Him to the great banquet was rebuked because of the smallness of his love; but she by her few tears atoned for the many follies of her offences.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:169
verses.text: Simon the Pharisee received our Lord as a prophet; because of the signs, and not because of faith.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:170
verses.text: For he was a son of Israel, who when signs drew near, himself also drew near to the Lord of the signs; and when the signs ceased, he also stood naked without faith.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:171
verses.text: This man also when he saw our Lord with signs, esteemed Him as a prophet; but when our Lord ceased from signs, the doubting mind of the sons of his people entered him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:172
verses.text: This man if He had been a prophet, He would have known that this woman is a sinner.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:173
verses.text: But our Lord for Whom in every place all things are easy, here also did not cease from His signs.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:174
verses.text: For He saw that because He had ceased a little from signs, the blind mind of the Pharisee had turned away from Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:175
verses.text: For he had said in error, This man, had He been a prophet, He would have known.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:176
verses.text: In this reflection therefore the Pharisee doubted concerning our Lord, whether He were a prophet or no; but by this very reflection he learned that He is Lord of the prophets; so that from the source from which error entered him, from that source our Lord might bring help to Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:178
verses.text: Our Lord then told him the parable of the two debtors; and made him judge; that by his tongue He might catch him in whose heart the truth was not.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:179
verses.text: One owed five hundred dinars.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:180
verses.text: Here then our Lord showed to the Pharisee the multitude of the offences of the sinful woman.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:181
verses.text: He then who imagined concerning our Lord that He did not know that she was a sinner, in the result heard from Him how great was the debt of her sins.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:182
verses.text: The Pharisee, then, who imagined that our Lord did not know who she was, and what was the reputation of the sinful woman, was found himself not to know who our Lord was, and what was His reputation.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:183
verses.text: Thus he was reproved in his error, who did not even perceive his error.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:184
verses.text: For the knowledge that he was assuredly erring eluded him in his error.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:185
verses.text: But he received a reminder from Him Who came to remind them that err.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:186
verses.text: The Pharisee had seen great signs done by our Lord, as Israel by Moses; but because there was not faith in him, that those prodigies which he saw might be conjoined with that faith, a little cause hindered and annulled them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:187
verses.text: Had this man been a prophet, he would have known that this woman is a sinner.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:188
verses.text: For he let slip the wonders that he had seen, and blindness readily entered into him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:189
verses.text: For he was of the sons of Israel, whom terrible signs accompanied up to the sea, that they might fear; and blessed miracles surrounded in the waste desert, that they might be reconciled; but through lack of faith, for a slight cause, they rejected them [saying]; As for this Moses who brought us up, we know not what has become of him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:190
verses.text: For they ceased to regard the mighty works that had been surrounding them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:191
verses.text: They perceived that Moses was not near them; so that for this cause that had come near, they drew [near] to the heathenism of Egypt.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:192
verses.text: For Moses was for a little removed from before them, that the calf that was before them might appear, that they might worship it openly also; for they had been secretly worshipping it in their hearts.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:194
verses.text: But when their heathenism from being inward became open, then Moses also from being hidden openly appeared; that he might openly punish those whose heathenism had revelled beneath the holy cloud which had overshadowed them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:195
verses.text: But God removed the Shepherd of the flock from it for forty days, that the flock might show that its trust was fixed upon the calf.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:196
verses.text: While God was feeding the flock with all delights, it chose for itself as its Shepherd the calf, which was not able even to eat.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:197
verses.text: Moses who kept them in awe was removed from them, that the idolatry might cry aloud in their mouths, which the restraint of Moses had kept down in their hearts.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:198
verses.text: For they cried:  Make us gods, to go before us.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:200
verses.text: But when Moses came down, he saw their heathenism revelling in the wide plain with drums and cymbals.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:201
verses.text: Speedily, he put their madness to shame by means of the Levites and drawn swords.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:202
verses.text: So likewise here, our Lord concealed His knowledge for a little when the sinful woman approached Him, that the Pharisee might form into shape his thought, as his fathers had shaped the pernicious calf.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:203
verses.text: But when the Pharisee's error came to a head within him, then the knowledge of our Lord was manifested against it and dispelled it; I entered into thy house; thou gavest Me no water for My feet:  But she has moistened them with her tears.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:204
verses.text: Therefore her sins which are many are forgiven her.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:205
verses.text: But the Pharisee when he heard our Lord naming the sins of the woman, many sins, was greatly put to shame because he had greatly erred.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:206
verses.text: For he had supposed that our Lord did not even know that she was a sinner.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:207
verses.text: Our Lord had before shown Himself as though not knowing her for a sinner.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:208
verses.text: For He allowed him who had seen His signs, to show the doubt of his mind, that it might become manifest that his mind was bound in the ungodliness of his fathers.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:209
verses.text: But the physician, who by his medicines brings out the hidden disease, is not the helper of the disease but its destroyer.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:210
verses.text: For while the disease is hidden, it rules in the members, but when it is made manifest by medicines, it is rooted out.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:211
verses.text: So then the Pharisee saw great things and doubted about small things.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:212
verses.text: But when our Lord saw that his littleness made little of great things in his mind, He speedily showed him not only that she was a sinner, but even the multitude of her sins; that he might be put to shame by little things,—he who had not believed in wonders.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:214
verses.text: God gave room to Israel to enlarge its heathenism in the wide desert; whom God cut short with whetted sword, that their idolatry might not be spread abroad among the Gentiles.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:215
verses.text: So our Lord allowed the Pharisee to imagine perverse things, that He might in turn duly reprove his pride.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:216
verses.text: For concerning those things which the sinful woman was doing rightly, the Pharisee was thinking wrongly.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:217
verses.text: But our Lord in His turn rebuked him, concerning the right things which he had wrongly withheld:  I entered thy house; thou gavest Me no water for My feet.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:218
verses.text: Behold the withholding of that which was due!  But she has moistened them with her tears.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:219
verses.text: Behold the payment of what was due!  Thou didst not anoint Me with oil.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:220
verses.text: Behold the token of neglect!  But she has anointed My feel with sweet ointment.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:221
verses.text: Behold the sign of zeal!  Thou didst not kiss Me.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:222
verses.text: Behold the testimony of enmity!  But she has not ceased to kiss My feet.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:223
verses.text: Behold the sign of love!  So then, by this enumeration our Lord showed that the Pharisee owed Him all those things and had withheld them; but that the sinful woman had come in and rendered all those things which he had withheld.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:224
verses.text: Because then she had paid the debts of him who wrongfully withheld them, the Just One forgave her, her own debt, even her sins.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:226
verses.text: Now the Pharisee, while he was doubting concerning our Lord, that He was not a prophet, pledged himself to the truth unawares, in saying—Had this man been a prophet, he would have known that this woman is a sinner.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:227
verses.text: Therefore, if it should be found that our Lord knew that she was a sinner, He is, according to thy word, O Pharisee, a prophet.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:228
verses.text: Our Lord, therefore, hastened to show both that she was a sinner, and that her sins were many; that the testimony of his own mouth might confute him as a liar.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:229
verses.text: For he was companion of those that said:  Who is able to forgive sins, but God only?  For from them our Lord received testimony, that, therefore, He Who is able to forgive sins, is God.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:230
verses.text: Thenceforth, then, the contention was this, that our Lord should show them whether He was able to forgive sins or no.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:231
verses.text: So He speedily healed the members that were visible, that it might be made sure that He had forgiven the sins that were invisible.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:232
verses.text: For our Lord cast before them the word which was expected to catch him that said it; so that when they should rush forward to catch Him by it, according to their wish, they might be caught by Him according to His wish.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:233
verses.text: Fear not, My son, thy sins are forgiven thee.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:234
verses.text: While they were hastening to catch Him on the charge of blasphemy, they pledged themselves unawares to the truth.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:235
verses.text: For Who is able forgive sins but God only?  Accordingly, our Lord confuted them [as though saying]:  "If I shall have shown that I am able to forgive sins, even though ye do not believe in Me that I am God; yet abide ye by your word, which determined that whoso forgives sins is God".

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:236
verses.text: Therefore that our Lord might teach them that He forgives sins, He forgave that man his hidden sin, and caused him to carry his bed openly; that by the carrying of the bed which carries [those that lie on it], they might believe in the slaying of the sin that slays.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:237
verses.text: This is a wonderful thing, that while our Lord there called Himself the Son of man, His adversaries, unawares, made Him to be God as forgiving sins.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:238
verses.text: Accordingly, while they supposed that they had ensnared Him by their craftiness, He entangled them in their craftiness; He made it a testimony to His truth.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:239
verses.text: So their evil thoughts became unto them as bitter bonds; and that they might not free themselves from their bonds, our Lord strengthened them by giving strength to him [to whom He said];—Arise, take up thy bed and go into thine house.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:240
verses.text: For the testimony could not again be undone, as though He were not God; inasmuch as He forgave sins.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:241
verses.text: Nor yet could it be falsely affirmed that He had not forgiven sins; for lo! He had healed [men's] limbs.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:242
verses.text: For our Lord bound up His hidden testimonies in those which were manifest; that their own testimony might choke the infidels.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:243
verses.text: Accordingly our Lord made their thoughts to war against them, because they had warred with the Good One, who by His healing power warred against their diseases.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:244
verses.text: For that which Simon the Pharisee imagined, and that which the scribes his companions imagined, they imagined in their hearts secretly; but our Lord spread it forth openly.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:245
verses.text: Our Lord represented their hidden imaginations before them, that they might learn that His knowledge reveals and shows their secret things(;) so that though they had not recognized Him by His open signs, they might recognize Him when He represented their secret imaginations; and that if only but by this,—that He searched out their hearts,—their hearts might perceive that He was God;—that at least when they saw that their imaginations could not be hidden from Him, they might cease from imagining evil against Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:246
verses.text: For they had imagined evil in their heart; but He exposed it openly, by this [word] Why are ye imagining evil in your heart?  So that by this, that our Lord perceived their hidden imagination, they should recognize His hidden Godhead.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:247
verses.text: For that Godhead, by this very thing that they in their error were reviling it, was by that reviling made known to them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:248
verses.text: For they reviled our Lord in the body, and supposed that He was not God, and cast Him down below from on high; but by the body He was made known to them as being God, by that body which was found passing to and fro amongst them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:249
verses.text: For they, by casting Him down to the depth, attempted to show this, that God Who is above, cannot in bodily wise be born below.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:250
verses.text: But He by His passage up to the height, taught them this; that for the body also that is sent down below, it is not its nature to pass up to the height rather than down to the depths; so that by the body which from below passed on high upwards in the air, they might learn of God that by His grace He descended down below from on high.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:252
verses.text: But why instead of a stern reproof did our Lord speak a parable of persuasion to that Pharisee?  He spoke the parable to him tenderly, that he, though froward, might unawares be enticed to correct his perversities.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:253
verses.text: For the waters that are congealed by the force of a cold wind, the heat of the sun gently dissolves.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:254
verses.text: So our Lord did not at once oppose him harshly, that he might not give occasion to the rebellious to rebel again.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:255
verses.text: But by blandishment He brought him under the yoke, that when he had been yoked, He might work with him, though rebellious, according to His will.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:256
verses.text: Now, because Simon was proudly minded, our Lord began humbly with him, that He might not be to him a teacher according to his folly.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:257
verses.text: For if that Pharisee retained the Pharisees' pride, how could our Lord cause him to acquire humility, when the treasure of humility was not under his hand?  But since our Lord was teaching humility to all men, He showed that His treasury was free from every form of pride.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:258
verses.text: But this was for our sakes, that He might teach us, that whatever treasuries pride enters into, it is by boastfulness that it gains access to them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:259
verses.text: On this account let not thy left hand know what thy right hand doeth.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:260
verses.text: Our Lord then did not employ harsh reproof, because His coming was of grace:  He did not refrain from reproof, because His later coming will be of retribution.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:261
verses.text: For He put men to fear in His coming of humility; because it is a fearful thing to fall into His hands when He shall come in flaming fire.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:262
verses.text: But our Lord bestowed the most part of His helps rather by persuasion than by reproof.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:263
verses.text: For the gentle shower softens the earth and penetrates all through it:  but violent rain binds and hardens the face of the earth, so that it does not receive it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:264
verses.text: For a harsh word excites wrath, and with it are bound up wrongs.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:265
verses.text: And when a harsh word has opened the door, wrath enters in, and at the heels of wrath, along with it enter in wrongs.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:267
verses.text: But because all helps attend on humble speech, He who came to render help employed it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:268
verses.text: Observe how mighty is the power of a humble word; for lo! by it vehement wrath is put down, and by it the billows of a swelling mind are calmed.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:269
verses.text: But hear whence this was.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:270
verses.text: That Pharisee thought, had this man been a prophet, he would have known.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:271
verses.text: Contempt as well as blasphemy can be discerned here.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:272
verses.text: Hear how our Lord in reply encountered this:  Simon, I have somewhat to say unto thee.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:273
verses.text: Love and reproof can be discerned here.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:274
verses.text: For this is a word of love such as friends use with their friends.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:275
verses.text: For when an adversary reproaches his adversary, he speaks not to him like this; for the madness of anger does not allow enemies to speak reasonably one to another.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:276
verses.text: But He Who prayed for them that crucified Him, that He might show that the fury of anger had no power over Him, was about to put to the question those that crucified Him, that He might show that He was governed by reason and not by anger.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:278
verses.text: Accordingly, our Lord placed a word of conciliation at the beginning of His speech, that by conciliation He might pacify the Pharisee, into whose mind discord and division had entered.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:279
verses.text: He was the physician who ranged His cures against the things hurtful [to men].

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:280
verses.text: Our Lord then shot forth this word as an arrow, and set in the head of it conciliation as the barb.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:281
verses.text: And He anointed it with love, that soothes the members; so that when it flew into him who was full of discord, he was at once changed from discord to harmony.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:282
verses.text: For straightway upon hearing that humble voice of our Lord, saying,—Simon, I have somewhat to say unto thee, that secret despiser returned his answer, Say on, Lord.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:283
verses.text: For the sweet voice entered his bitter mind, and begot of it pleasant fruit.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:284
verses.text: For he who before this voice was one that secretly despised, after this voice became one that openly honoured.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:285
verses.text: For humility, by its sweet utterance, subdues even its adversaries into rendering it honour.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:286
verses.text: For it is not over its friends that humility tests its power, but over its enemies it exhibits its victories.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:288
verses.text: Thus the heavenly King arrayed Himself in armour of humility, and so conquered the bitter one, and drew from him a good answer as a sure pledge [of victory].

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:289
verses.text: This is the armour concerning which Paul said, that by it we humble the loftiness that exalteth itself against the knowledge of God.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:290
verses.text: For Paul had received the proof of it in himself.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:291
verses.text: For as he had been warring in pride, but was conquered in humility, so is to be conquered every lofty thing which exalteth itself against this humility.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:292
verses.text: For Saul was journeying to subdue the disciples with hard words, but the Master of the disciples subdued him with a humble word.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:293
verses.text: For when He to whom all things are possible manifested Himself to him, giving up all things else, He spoke to him in humility alone, that He might teach us that a soft tongue is more effectual than all things else against hard thoughts.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:294
verses.text: For neither threats nor words of terror were heard by Paul, but weak words not able to avenge themselves:  Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou Me?  But the words which were thought not even capable of avenging themselves, were found to be taking vengeance by drawing him away from the Jews and making him a goodly vessel.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:295
verses.text: He who was full of the bitter will of the Jews, was then filled with the sweet preaching of the cross.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:296
verses.text: When he was filled with the bitterness of the crucifiers, in his bitterness he made havoc of the churches.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:297
verses.text: But when he was filled with the sweetness of the Crucified, he embittered the synagogues of the crucifiers.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:298
verses.text: Our Lord then strove with humble voice with him, who had been warring against His churches with hard bonds.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:299
verses.text: Thus Saul, who had been binding the disciples with bitter chains, was bound with pleasant persuasions; that he might not again cast the disciples into bonds; since he was bound by the Crucified, Who puts to silence evil voices, whom all they that were set against Him could not bind or injure.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:300
verses.text: But when Paul ceased from binding the disciples, he himself was bound with chains by the persecutors.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:301
verses.text: But when he was bound with chains, he loosed the bonds of idolatry by his bonds.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:303
verses.text: Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?  He who had conquered His persecutors in the world below, and ruled over the angels in the world above, spoke from above with humble voice.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:304
verses.text: And He Who while He was upon earth had denounced ten woes against His crucifiers, when He was in heaven, did not denounce even one woe against Saul, His persecutor.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:305
verses.text: Now, our Lord denounced woe to His crucifiers, that He might teach His disciples not to be dismayed by His murderers.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:306
verses.text: But our Lord spoke in humility from heaven, that in humility the heads of His church might speak.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:307
verses.text: And if any one should say, "Wherein did our Lord speak humbly with Paul? for lo! the eyes of Paul were grievously smitten;" let him know that it was not from our merciful Lord that this chastisement proceeded, who spoke those words in humility; but from the vehement light that vehemently shone forth there.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:308
verses.text: And this light did not strike Paul by way of retribution on account of his deeds, but on account of the vehemence of its rays it hurt him, as he also said:  When I arose, I could discern nothing for the glory of the light.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:309
verses.text: But if that light was glorious, O Paul, how did the glorious light become a blinding light to thee thyself?  The light was that which, according to its nature, illuminates above, but contrary to its nature, it shone forth below.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:310
verses.text: When it illumined above, it was delightful; but when it shone forth below, it was blinding.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:311
verses.text: For the light was both grievous and pleasant.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:312
verses.text: It was grievous and violent towards the eyes of the flesh; and it was pleasant and lightful to those who are fire and spirit.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:314
verses.text: For I saw a light from heaven that excelled the sun, and its light shone upon me.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:315
verses.text: So then mighty rays streamed forth without moderation, and were poured upon feeble eyes, which moderate rays refresh.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:316
verses.text: For, lo! the sun also in measure assists the eyes, but beyond measure and out of measure it injures the eyes.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:317
verses.text: And it is not by way of vengeance in wrath that it smites them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:318
verses.text: For lo! it is the friend of the eyes and beloved of the eyeballs.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:319
verses.text: And this is a marvel; while with its gentle lustre it befriends and assists the eyes; yet by its vehement rays it is hostile to and injures the eyeballs.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:320
verses.text: But if the sun which is here below, and of kindred nature with the eyes that are here below, yet injures them, in vehemence and not in anger, in its proper force and not in wrath; how much more should the light that is from above, akin to the things that are above, by its vehemence injure a man here below who has suddenly gazed upon that which is not akin to his nature?  For since Paul might have been injured by the vehemence of this sun to which he was accustomed, if he gazed upon it not according to custom, how much more should he be injured by the glory of that light to which his eyes never had been accustomed?  For behold, Daniel also was melted and poured out on every side before the glory of the angel, whose vehement brightness suddenly shone upon him! and it was not because of the angel's wrath that his human weakness was melted, just as it is not on account of the wrath or hostility of fire that wax is melted before it; but on account of the weakness of the wax it cannot keep firm and stand in presence of fire.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:321
verses.text: When then the two approach one another, the power of the fire by its quality prevails; but the weakness of the wax on the other hand is brought lower even than its former weakness.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:323
verses.text: But the majesty of the angel was manifested in itself; the weakness of flesh in itself could not endure.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:324
verses.text: For my inward parts were turned into corruption.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:325
verses.text: But yet men see men, their fellows, and faint before them:  Yet it is not by their bright splendour that they are moved, but by their harsh will.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:326
verses.text: For servants are terrified by the wrath of their masters, and those that are judged tremble through fear of their judges.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:327
verses.text: But this did not befall Daniel on account of threatening or anger from the angel; but on account of his terrible nature and prevailing brightness.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:328
verses.text: For it was not with threatening, the angel came to him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:329
verses.text: For if he had come with threatening, how could a mouth full of threatening become full of peace, when it came, saying, Peace be unto thee, thou man of desire?  Thus that mouth that was a fountain of thunderings—for the voice of his words was like the voice of many hosts, that voice became to him a fountain teeming with and containing peace.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:330
verses.text: And when [the voice] reached the terrified ears which were athirst for the encouraging greeting of peace, there was opened and poured out [for Daniel] a draught of peace.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:331
verses.text: And by the angel's later [word of] peace, those ears were encouraged, which had been terrified by his former voice first.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:332
verses.text: For [he said], Let my Lord speak because I have been strengthened.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:333
verses.text: But because in that heart-moving vision the fiery angel was about to announce nothing concerning Him, [the Lord], on this account that majesty [of the angel] was forward to give the salutation of peace to the lowliness [of the prophet]; that by the gladdening salutation which that awful majesty gave, the dread should be removed which lay on the mind of the lowliness and that was terrified.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:335
verses.text: But what shall we say about the Lord of the Angel, Who said to Moses,—No man shall see Me and live?  Is it on account of the fury of His anger, that whoso shall see Him shall die?  Or on account of the splendour of His Being?  For that Being was not made and was not created:  so that eyes which have been made and created cannot look upon it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:336
verses.text: For if it is on account of His fury that whoso shall look upon Him shall not live, lo! He would have granted to Moses to see Him because of His great love to him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:337
verses.text: Accordingly, the Self-Existent by His vision slays them that look upon Him; but He slays, not because of harsh fury but because of His potent splendour.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:338
verses.text: Because of this He in His great love granted to Moses to see His glory; yet in the same great love He restrained him from seeing His glory.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:339
verses.text: But it was not that the glory of His majesty would have been at all diminished, but that weak eyes could not suffice to bear the overpowering billows of His glory.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:340
verses.text: Therefore God, Who in His love desired that the vision of Moses should be directed upon the goodly brightness of His glory, in His love did not desire that the vision of Moses should be blinded amidst the potent rays of His glory.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:341
verses.text: Therefore Moses saw and saw not.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:342
verses.text: He saw, that he might be exalted; he saw not, that he might not be injured.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:343
verses.text: For by that which he saw, his lowliness was exalted; and by that which he saw not, his weakness was not blinded.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:344
verses.text: As also our eyes look upon the sun and look not upon it; and by what they see are assisted; and by what they see not, are uninjured.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:345
verses.text: Thus the eye sees, that it may be benefited; but it ventures not [to look], that it may not be injured.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:346
verses.text: So then through love God hindered Moses from seeing that glory that was too hard for his eyes:  As also Moses through his love prevented the children of his people from seeing the brightness that was too strong for their eyes.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:347
verses.text: For he learned from Him Who covered him, and spread His hand, and hid from him the splendour of the glory, that it might not injure him; so that he also should spread the veil and conceal from the feeble ones the overpowering splendour, that it might not hurt them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:348
verses.text: Now when Moses saw that the sons of perishable flesh could not gaze upon the borrowed glory that was on his face, his heart failed within him; for that he had sought to dare to gaze upon the glory of the Eternal Being; in whose floods, lo! those above and those below are plunged and spring forth; the depths whereof none can fathom; the shores whereof none can reach; whereof no end or limit can be found.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:350
verses.text: Now if any one should say, "Was it not then possible for God [to bring it to pass] that Moses should look upon that glory and not be injured; and that Paul likewise should look upon the light and take no hurt?"  Let him that says this understand that though it is possible for the power and overruling force of God, that the eyes should change their nature; yet it is inconsistent with the wisdom and nature of God that the order of nature should be confused.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:351
verses.text: For, lo! it is also easy for the arm of the artificer to destroy [his fabrics]; but it is inconsistent with the good sense of the artificer to ruin goodly ornaments.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:352
verses.text: And if any one wishes to say, concerning something which to himself seems meet;—"It were meet for God to do this;" let him know that it is meet for himself not to speak thus concerning God.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:353
verses.text: For the chief of all things meet is this:  that a man should not teach God what is meet.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:354
verses.text: For it becomes not man to become God's instructor.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:355
verses.text: For this is a great wickedness, that we should become teachers to Him, of Whom these created mouths of ours are unable to tell, in the formation of His handiwork.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:356
verses.text: For it is an unpardonable iniquity, that the mouth in its boldness should teach what is proper to that God by Whose grace it learned to speak at all.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:357
verses.text: If any one then shall say, "It had been meet for God to do this," I also, because I have a mouth and a tongue, may say, "It had been meet for God not to give to man freedom by which he thus reproaches Him Who is not to be reproached".

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:358
verses.text: But I do not dare to say that it was not meet for Him to give it; lest I also make myself an instructor of Him Who is not to be instructed.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:359
verses.text: For because He is just, He would have been reproached by Himself, had He not given freedom to men, as though through grudging He had withheld from lowly man the gift that makes great.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:360
verses.text: Therefore He gave it betimes by His grace, that He might not be justly reproached by Himself; even though through freedom, His own gift, lo! blasphemers wickedly reproach Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:362
verses.text: Now why were the eyes of Moses made to shine because of the glory which he saw, while on the contrary [the eyes of] Paul, instead of being made to shine, were made utterly blind?  Yet we may be sure that the eyes of Moses were not stronger than those of Paul; for they were akin in one brotherhood of blood and flesh.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:363
verses.text: But another power through grace sustained the eyes of Moses; whereas no power was added in mercy to the eyes of Paul, beyond their natural power, which in wrath was taken from them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:364
verses.text: But if we say that their natural power was taken away from them, and that [it was] on this account he was defeated and overcome by the overpowering light,—for had their natural power remained, they would have been able to endure that supernatural light.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:365
verses.text: Yet let us be sure of this, that as often as anything transcendent is revealed, that surpasses and transcends our nature, our natural power is not able to stand before it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:366
verses.text: But if on the other hand another power beyond our natural one is added to us, then by that power received by us in excess of and beyond nature, we shall be able to stand before any strange thing which comes upon us supernaturally.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:368
verses.text: For, lo! the power of our ears and eyes is in us and is formed in us in its natural manner; and yet our sight and hearing cannot stand before mighty thunderings and lightnings; first, because they come with vehemence; and secondly, because their potency suddenly surprises and astounds our feebleness.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:369
verses.text: This is what happened to Paul.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:370
verses.text: For the potency of the light suddenly surprised his feeble eyes and injured them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:371
verses.text: But the greatness of the voice brought low his strength and entered his ears and opened them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:372
verses.text: For they had been closed up by Jewish contentiousness as by wax.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:373
verses.text: For the voice did not plough up the ears, as the light injured the eyeballs.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:374
verses.text: Why? but because it was meet that he should hear, but not that he should see.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:375
verses.text: Therefore the doors of hearing were opened by the voice as by a key:  but the doors of sight were shut by the light that should open them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:376
verses.text: Why then was it meet that he should hear?  Clearly because by that voice our Lord was able to reveal Himself as being persecuted by Saul.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:377
verses.text: For He was not able to show Himself by sight as being persecuted; for there was no way whereby this should be, that the son of David should be seen fleeing and Saul pursuing after Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:378
verses.text: For this happened in very deed with that first Saul and with the first David.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:379
verses.text: The one was pursuing; the other was being persecuted; they both of them saw and were seen, each by the other.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:380
verses.text: But here the ear alone could hear of the persecution of the Son of David; the eye could not see that He was being persecuted.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:381
verses.text: For it was in [the person of] others He was being persecuted, while He was Himself in heaven;—He Who beforetime had been persecuted in His own person while He was upon earth.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:382
verses.text: Therefore the ears [of Saul] were opened and his eyes were closed.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:383
verses.text: And He Who by sight could not represent Himself before Saul as persecuted, represented Himself by word before him as persecuted; when he cried and said;—Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou Me?  Accordingly, his eyes were closed, because they could not see the persecution of Christ; but his ears were opened, because they could hear of His persecution.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:384
verses.text: So then although the eyes of Moses were bodily eyes, as those of Paul, yet his inward eyes were Christian; for Moses wrote of Me, but the outward eyes of Paul were open, while the inward [eyes] were shut.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:385
verses.text: Then because the inward eyes of Moses shone clear, his outward eyes also were made to shine clearly.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:386
verses.text: But the outward eyes of Paul were closed, that by the closing of those that were outward, there might come to pass the opening of those that were inward.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:387
verses.text: For he who by the outward eyes was not able to see the Lord in His signs, he when those bodily eyes were closed, saw with those within.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:388
verses.text: And because he had received the proof in his own person, he wrote to those who had their bodily eyes full of light;—May He illumine the eyes of your hearts.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:389
verses.text: Therefore the signs manifested to the external eyes of the Jews, profited them not at all; but faith of the heart opened the eyes of the heart of the Gentiles.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:390
verses.text: But because, had Moses come down in his accustomed aspect from the mountain, without that shining of countenance, and said, "I saw there the glory of God," the faithless fathers would not have believed him; so also, had Paul, without suffering blindness of his eyes, said, "I heard the voice of Christ," the sons who crucified Christ would not have received it as true.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:391
verses.text: Therefore He set on Moses as in love, an excelling sign of splendour, that the deceivers might believe that he had seen the Divine glory; but on Saul, as on a persecutor, He set the hateful sign of blindness, that the liars might believe that he had heard the words of Christ; that so thou might not again speak against Moses, and that these might not doubt concerning Paul.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:392
verses.text: For God set signs on the bodies of the blind, and sent them to those who were in error, who used to make signs upon the borders of their garments.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:393
verses.text: But they remembered not the signs on their garments, and in the signs of the body they greatly erred.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:394
verses.text: The fathers who saw the glory of Moses, did not obey Moses; nor did the sons who saw the blindness of Paul believe Paul.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:395
verses.text: But three times in the desert they threatened to stone Moses and his house with stones as dogs.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:396
verses.text: For all congregation bade stone them with stones.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:397
verses.text: And thrice they scourged Paul with rods as a dog on his body.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:398
verses.text: [?]  Thrice was I beaten with rods.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:399
verses.text: These are the lions who through their love for their Lord were beaten as dogs and were torn as flocks of sheep, those flocks that used to stone their guardian shepherds, in order that ravening wolves might rule over them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:401
verses.text: But the crucifiers who corrupted the soldiers with a bribe, they perhaps said concerning Paul;—"The disciples have bribed him with a bribe; therefore he associates with the disciples".

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:402
verses.text: For those who by the giving of a bribe strove that the resurrection of our Lord might not be preached, slandered Paul with the name of a bribe, that his revelation might not be believed.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:403
verses.text: Therefore the voice astonished him, and the light blinded him, that his astonishment might pacify his violence, and his blindness might put to shame his slanderers.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:404
verses.text: For the voice astounded his hearing in this, that it said meekly to him;—(Saul, why persecutes thou Me?):  and the light blinded his sight, that when the slanderers should have said that he had received a bribe, and thereby was suborned to lie, his blindness which had been brought about by that light might confute them, showing that it was through it that he had been driven to speak what was true.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:405
verses.text: So that those who supposed that his hands had received a bribe, and that because of it his lips lied, might know that his eyes had given up their light and because of this his lips proclaimed the truth.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:406
verses.text: But again for another reason the meek voice accompanied the overpowering light; namely, that as it were from meekness unto exaltation our Lord might produce help for the persecutor; in like manner as also all His helps were produced, from lowliness unto greatness.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:407
verses.text: For our Lord's meekness continued from the womb to the tomb.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:408
verses.text: And observe that greatness comes close upon His lowliness, and exaltation on His meekness.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:409
verses.text: For whereas His greatness was observed in divers things, His Divinity was revealed by glorious signs; that it might be known that the One Who stood amongst them, was not one but two.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:410
verses.text: For His nature is not humble nature alone, nor is it an exalted nature alone; but there are two natures that are mingled, the one with the other; the exalted and the humble.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:411
verses.text: Therefore these two natures show forth their qualities; so that by the quality of each of the two, mankind might distinguish between the two; that it might not be supposed that He was merely one,—He Who was two by commingling:  but that it might be known that He was two in respect of the blending, though He was one in respect of His Being.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:412
verses.text: These things our Lord, through His humility and exaltation, taught to Paul also in the way to Damascus.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:414
verses.text: For our Lord appeared to Saul in meekness, since meekness was close to His greatness; that because of His greatness it might be known Who He is Who spake meekly.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:415
verses.text: For even as His disciples preached on earth of our Lord in meekness and in exaltation,—in the meekness of His persecution, and in the exaltation of His signs,—so also our Lord preached of Himself in meekness and in exaltation in Paul's presence—in the exaltation of the potency of the light which flashed, and in the meekness of that meek voice which said; Saul, why persecutest thou Me?—so that the preaching of Him which His disciples preached concerning Him in presence of many, should be like to that preaching which He preached concerning Himself.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:416
verses.text: But even as, if He had not spoken meekly, it would not have been made known there that He was meek, so, had He not appeared there as an overpowering light, it would not have been made known there that He was exalted.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:418
verses.text: And if thou shouldst say; "What necessity was there that He should speak humbly?  Could He not have convinced him also through the greatness of the light?"  Know, thou that questionest, that this rejoinder may be returned to thee; that because it was necessary that He should speak humbly, He therefore spoke humbly.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:419
verses.text: For by Him Who is wise in all things, there was done there nothing that was not meet to be done.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:420
verses.text: For He Who has given knowledge to artificers to do each thing severally with the instrument meet for it, does He not Himself know that which He gives others the power of knowing?  Therefore whatsoever has been wrought or is being wrought by the Godhead, that very thing that is wrought by Him at that time, is for the furtherance of [God's] working at that time, even though to the blind the Divine orderings seem contrariwise.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:421
verses.text: But that we may not restrain by constraint of words a wise enquirer, one that wishes to grow by true persuasion as the seed by the rain-drops; know, O enquirer, that because Saul was a persecutor, but our Lord was endeavouring to make him persecuted instead of persecutor, therefore He of His wisdom made haste to cry—Saul, why persecutest thou Me?—in order that, when Saul who was being made a disciple, heard Him Who was making him a disciple, saying, Why persecutest thou Me? he might know that the Master Whose servant he was becoming, was a persecuted Master, and so might quickly cast away the persecution of his former masters, and might clothe himself in the persecuted state of his persecuted Master.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:422
verses.text: Now any master who wishes to teach a man anything, teaches him either by deeds or by words.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:423
verses.text: But if he teach him neither by words nor by deeds, the man cannot be instructed in his craft.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:424
verses.text: So that, even though our Lord did not teach Paul humility by deeds, yet by voice He taught him endurance of persecution which He could not teach him by deed.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:425
