verses.text: For before our Lord was crucified, He taught His disciples humble endurance of persecution by deed.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:426
verses.text: But after He had finished His persecution by crucifixion, as He said, Lo! all things are finished.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:427
verses.text: He could not vainly return and begin again anything which once for all had been wisely finished.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:428
verses.text: Or why again do ye seek for the crucifixion and shame of the Son of God?  36.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:429
verses.text: For even though our Lord in His grace had beforetime brought the majesty of His Godhead into humility, yet afterwards in His justice He willed not again to bring back to humiliation the littleness of manhood which had been made great.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:430
verses.text: But because it was necessary that the persecuting disciple should learn endurance of persecution, while yet it was impossible that the Master should again come down and be persecuted afresh; He taught him by voice that which could not be taught by deeds.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:431
verses.text: Saul, why persecutest thou Me?  The explanation of which utterance is this;—"Saul, why art thou not persecuted in Me?"  But in order that Saul might not suppose that it was because of His weakness our Lord was persecuted, the strength of the overpowering light which shone upon him, convinced him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:432
verses.text: For if the eyes of Saul could not endure the shining of that light, how could the hands of Saul bind and fetter the disciples of the Lord of that light?  But his hands had fettered the disciples, that he might learn their power in their bonds; while his eyes could not endure the beams, that by their strength he might learn his own weakness.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:433
verses.text: But had not the power of that light shone upon him, when the Lord said to him; Saul, why persecutest thou Me?  Then because of the madness of the pride wherein Paul was set up at that time, he would perhaps have said this to Him, "I am persecuting Thee for this reason, because Thou hast said, Why persecutest thou Me?  For who is there that would not persecute Thee, when Thou, with such strength, troublest Thy persecutor with these feeble cries".

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:434
verses.text: But the humility of our Lord was heard in the voice, and the power of the light shone forth in the beams.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:435
verses.text: So Paul could not despise the humility of the voice, because of the glory of the light.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:437
verses.text: Thus were his ears brought into discipleship to the voice which he heard, because his eyes sufficed not to endure the beams which they saw.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:438
verses.text: That marvel of the dawning of the light was shed forth upon his eyeballs and did them hurt; and the voice of the Lord of the light entered his ears, but did them no harm.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:439
verses.text: But between the light and the Lord of the light, which ought to have been the stronger?  For if the light which was created by Him was so overpowering, how much more overpowering He by Whom this very light was created!  But if the Lord of the light was overpowering, as indeed He is overpowering, how did His voice enter the hearing and not harm it? even as that light which hurt the sight?  But hear the wonder and the marvel which our Lord wrought by His grace.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:440
verses.text: For our Lord willed not to humble that light which is His; but He being Lord of the light humbled Himself.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:441
verses.text: But as the Lord of the light is greater than the light which is His, so great is the glory that the Lord of the light should humble Himself rather than humble the light.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:443
verses.text: As also in the night, while He was praying, it is written;—There appeared to Him an angel strengthening Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:444
verses.text: But here all mouths, celestial and terrestrial, are insufficient to give thanks to Him by Whose hand the angels were created; that He was strengthened for the sake of sinners by that angel who was created by His hand.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:445
verses.text: As then the angel from above stood in glory and in brightness, while the Lord of the angel, that He might exalt man who was degraded, stood in degradation and humility; so also here that light flashed forth in manifestation; but the Lord of the light, for the sake of helping one persecutor, spoke with humble voice and lowly words.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:447
verses.text: For this cause therefore that light which was overpowering, because it was not diminished, entered the eyeballs with overpowering manifestation and injured them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:448
verses.text: But the Lord of the light, because He had lowered Himself in order to help, His lowly voice entered the ears that had need and helped them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:449
verses.text: But in order that the help of that voice which had become lowly, might not fail Him, therefore the strength of that light was not lowered, in order that because of that light, which was not lowered, the help of that voice which was lowered, might be believed.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:450
verses.text: But this is a marvel, that until our Lord made Himself lowly in voice, Paul was not made lowly in deed; for even as, before He came down and clothed Himself in a body, our Lord was in exaltation with His Father; yet in His exaltation men did not learn humility; but when He humbled Himself and came down from His exaltation, then by His humbleness humility was soon among men; so again after His resurrection and ascension He was in glory at the right hand of God His Father, but by that His exaltation, Paul did not learn humility.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:451
verses.text: Therefore He that was exalted and sat at the right hand of His Father, ceased from glorious and lofty speech, and He cried as one wronged and oppressed, with feeble and meek words, saying,—Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou Me?  Thus, humble words prevailed over harsh bridles.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:452
verses.text: For by humble words, as by bridles, the persecuted led the persecutor from the broad way of the persecutors into the narrow way of the persecuted.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:453
verses.text: And since all the signs that were done in the Name of our Lord did not convince Paul, our Lord made haste to meet with humility him who was hastening on the way to Damascus in the vehemence of pride.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:454
verses.text: Thus by His humble words, the harsh vehemence of pride was checked.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:456
verses.text: He then Who used humble words with Paul His persecutor, He also used humble sayings with the Pharisee.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:457
verses.text: For so great is the power of humility that even God Who overcomes all did not overcome without it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:458
verses.text: Humility was able also in the wilderness to bear the burden of the stiff-necked people.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:459
verses.text: For against the people who were more stubborn than all men, was set Moses who was more meek than all men.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:460
verses.text: For God Who needs not anything, when He had set free the people, afterwards had need of the humility of Moses, that this humility might endure the wrath and murmuring of the People that provoked him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:461
verses.text: For humility alone could endure the gainsayings of that people, which the signs of Egypt and the prodigies (wrought) in the desert could not subdue.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:462
verses.text: For when pride had wrought divisions amongst the people, humility by its prayer used to close up their divisions.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:463
verses.text: If then the humility of the Stammerer endured six hundred thousand, how much more exceedingly did the humility of Him, Who gave speech to the Stammerer endure?  For the humility of Moses is a shadow of the humility of our Lord.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:465
verses.text: Our Lord then saw that Simon the Pharisee did not believe the signs and wonders which he had seen.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:466
verses.text: He came to him to persuade him with humble words; and humble utterances overcame him, whom mighty wonders had not overcome.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:467
verses.text: What then are the wonders which that Pharisee had seen?  He had seen the dead raised to life, the lepers cleansed, the blind with eyes opened.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:468
verses.text: These signs compelled that Pharisee to entertain our Lord as a prophet.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:469
verses.text: But he who entertained Him as a prophet, changed so as to despise Him for one who had not knowledge, saying (namely);—Had this man been a prophet, He would have known that this woman—who had approached Him—is a sinner.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:470
verses.text: But we may despise the Pharisee and say, Had he been a man of discernment, he would have learned from that sinful woman, who approached our Lord, not that He was a prophet, but the Lord of the Prophets.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:471
verses.text: For the tears of the sinful woman testified, that it was not a prophet they were propitiating, but Him, Who, as God, was wroth with her sins.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:472
verses.text: For, because the prophets sufficed not to raise sinners to life, the Lord of the prophets came down to heal those who were in evil case.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:473
verses.text: But what physician is there who hinders the smitten, that they should not come to him, O blind Pharisee, as it befel that she came to our Physician!  For why did the smitten woman approach Him,—she, whose wounds were healed by her tears?  He Who had come down to be a fountain of healing amongst the diseased, was proclaiming this;—Let every one that is athirst, come and drink.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:474
verses.text: But when the Pharisees, this man's companions, murmured at the healing of sinners, the Physician taught concerning His art, that the door is opened for the diseased and not for the whole, for they that are whole need not a physician but they that are sick.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:475
verses.text: Therefore the praise of the physician is the healing of the diseased;—that the shame of the Pharisee who reproved the praise of our physician may be greater.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:476
verses.text: But our Lord used to show signs in the streets; and also when He entered into the house of the Pharisee, He showed signs which were greater than those He had shown outside.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:477
verses.text: For in the street He made whole the bodies that were sick, but within He healed the souls that were diseased.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:478
verses.text: Outside, He raised to life the mortality of Lazarus:  but within, He raised to life the mortality of the sinful woman.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:479
verses.text: He restored the living soul to the corpse from which it had gone out; and He expelled from the sinful woman the deadly sin which dwelt within her.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:480
verses.text: But the blind (Pharisee) who was insufficient for great things, because of the great things which he saw not, belied those small things which he had seen.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:481
verses.text: For he was a son of Israel who attributed weakness to his God, and not to himself.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:482
verses.text: For (Israel said), Though He smote the rock and the waters flowed, can He also give us bread?  But when our Lord saw his weakness, that it missed the great things and, because of them, the small things also, He hasted to put forward a simple word, as though for a babe that was being reared on milk, and was not capable of solid food.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:484
verses.text: For by that wherein thou knewest, O Pharisee, that our Lord was not a prophet, by that very thing it was proved that thou didst not know the prophets.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:485
verses.text: For by this that thou saidst;—Had this man been a prophet, he would have known, thou showest herein that (in thy esteem) whoever is a prophet knows all things.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:486
verses.text: But lo! some matters were hidden from the prophets; how then dost thou attribute the revelation of all hidden things to the prophets?  But this unwise teacher who perverted the scriptures of the Prophets, did not even understand what he read in the scriptures.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:487
verses.text: For it was not only that the greatness of the Lord was not discerned by that Pharisee, but he did not even discern the weakness of the prophets.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:488
verses.text: For our Lord, as knowing all things, allowed that sinful woman to come in and receive His peace.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:489
verses.text: But Elisha, as one ignorant, said to the Shunamite;—Peace to thee and peace be to the child.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:490
verses.text: Accordingly he who supposed that our Lord was proved not to be a prophet, was himself proved not to know the Prophets.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:491
verses.text: When the mind contains malice and cannot refrain, then that malice which is in it, is cunning in finding a pretext for opening a door; but in case that pretext, in which the deceiver takes refuge is confuted, he knows that within this there is another concealed which he may employ.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:492
verses.text: Now observe this son of Israel, how he was like Israel in stubbornness.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:493
verses.text: For heathenism was bound up in the mind of the People; therefore Moses was taken away from them, that the wickedness that was within them might become manifest.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:494
verses.text: But that they might not be put to shame, and that it might not be known how they were seeking idols, they first sought for Moses, and then for idols.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:495
verses.text: As for this Moses, we know not what has become of him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:496
verses.text: And if God, Who cannot die, brought thee out of Egypt, why dost thou seek for a man, who at some time must die?  Yet they did not desire Moses, that he should become a god to them; because Moses could hear and see and reprove; but they sought for a god who could neither hear nor see nor reprove.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:497
verses.text: But whensoever Moses shall have died, what shall remain of him?  For behold, thy God is a living God, and lo! He has revealed Himself to thee by living testimonies.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:498
verses.text: For the bright cloud was at that time overshadowing them, and they had the pillar of light in the night-time.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:499
verses.text: Water flowed for them from the rock, and they drank its streams.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:500
verses.text: They were delighted every day by tasting that manna, the fame of which we have heard.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:501
verses.text: How was Moses far from thee?  Behold the signs of Moses surround thee.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:502
verses.text: Or how does the person of Moses profit thee, when thou hast such a guide as this?  If thy garments wear not old, and a temperate air refreshes thee, if the heat and the cold do not hurt thee, and thou hast rest from war, and art far removed from the fear of Egypt,—what thing then was lacking to Israel that he sought for Moses?  Open heathenism was lacking to him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:503
verses.text: For it was not for Moses that he sought, but on the pretext of Moses' absence he followed after the calf.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:504
verses.text: Thus briefly have we showed, that when the mind is full of anything, but an opposing reason meets it, then it forces it by violence to open for it a door to that which it desires.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:506
verses.text: Thou too, O Pharisee, athirst for blasphemy, what sawest thou in our Lord, to show that He was not a prophet?  For lo! the things that belong to the Lord of the Prophets were seen in Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:507
verses.text: For the gushing tears made haste to proclaim that they were shed as before God.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:508
verses.text: The sorrowing kisses testified that they sought to win over the creditor to tear up the debt-bonds.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:509
verses.text: The goodly ointment of the sinful woman proclaimed that it was a bribe of penitence.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:510
verses.text: These medicines the sinful woman offered to her Physician, that by her tears He might wash away her stains, by her kisses He might heal her wounds, by her sweet ointment He might make her evil name sweet as the odour of her ointment.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:511
verses.text: This is the Physician who heals men by the medicines which they bring to Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:512
verses.text: These marvels were shown at that time; but to the Pharisee instead of these there appeared blasphemy.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:513
verses.text: For what could be established in the weeping of the sinful woman, but that He can justify sinners?  Else, judge thou in thy mind, O blind teacher, why was that mournful weeping in the joyful feast, so that, while they were making merry with food, she was in bitterness with her tears?  Because she was a sinner, her deeds were unchaste, and these (deeds) she was wont to do.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:514
verses.text: But if at that time, from the wantonness of sinners she was turned to chastity, then acknowledge, thou who saidst He is not a prophet, that He is One who makes those chaste that have been wanton.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:515
verses.text: For by this, that thou knowest that she is a sinner, and by this, that thou seest her now penitent, search out where is the power that changed her.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:516
verses.text: For he ought to have fallen down and worshipped Him Who, while silent, in His silence turned to chastity those sinners whom the Prophets by their vehement utterances could not turn to chastity.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:517
verses.text: A wonderful and marvellous thing was seen in the house of the Pharisee; a sinful woman that sat and wept, and she who wept said not wherefore she wept; nor did He at Whose feet she sat say to her, Why weepest thou?  The sinner did not need with her lips to petition our Lord, because she believed that He knew, as God, the petitions that were hidden in her tears.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:518
verses.text: Nor did our Lord ask her, What hast thou done?  For He knew that by her pure kisses she was atoning for her transgressions.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:519
verses.text: So then she, because she believed that He knew the things that were hidden, offered to Him her prayers in her heart; for knowing secret things He had no need of the outward lips.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:520
verses.text: If then the sinner, because she knew that our Lord was God, sought not to persuade Him with her lips; and our Lord, because as God He discerned her thoughts, therefore questioned her not; dost not thou, O tyrant Pharisee, from the silence of both understand the position of both; that she was praying as to God in her heart, and that He as God was in silence searching out her thoughts?  But the Pharisee could not see and understand these things, because he was a son of Israel who though perceiving, saw not, and though he heard, understood not.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:521
verses.text: Though then our Lord knew that that Pharisee thought evil thoughts concerning Him, He confuted him gently and not harshly.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:522
verses.text: For sweetness came down from on high to break down the bitterness with which the Evil One had stamped us.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:523
verses.text: Therefore our Lord taught that Pharisee of Himself and in Himself, as though saying, Even as I, though I knew the evil things in thy heart, yet gently persuaded thee, so though I knew the evil things of this woman, I mercifully received her.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:524
verses.text: But let us hear how long-suffering was drawn after the hasty thought, so as to draw it from haste to understanding.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:525
verses.text: A certain creditor had two debtors.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:526
verses.text: One owed five hundred dinars, and the other fifty dinars.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:527
verses.text: —(Be not wearied, O hearer, at the length of the repetition of the parable, lest thou be contrary to Him Who in the parable was long-suffering for the sake of giving help.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:528
verses.text: )—At length, when neither of them had wherewithal to pay, he forgave them both.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:529
verses.text: Which of them dost thou think would love him more?  Simon said to Him, I suppose that he, to whom more was forgiven.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:530
verses.text: Our Lord said to him, Thou has rightly judged.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:531
verses.text: Our Lord in His justice commended the perverse (Pharisee), because of the right judgment, which he had judged, though he in his wickedness had answered the good Lord concerning the mercy He had wrought.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:532
verses.text: Now many things are laid up in this parable; for it is a treasury full of many helps.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:533
verses.text: Why then did our Lord require that the Pharisee should pass judgment for Him between the two debtors?  Was it not that the greatness, coming after the littleness, might show itself that nothing of the littleness was drawn after the greatness?  For our Lord, since He knew the secret things, was long-suffering and questioned Simon, that those might be put to shame who, though not knowing, were hasty to blame, but not to enquire.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:534
verses.text: For if, O man, before I heard thy judgment passed, I judged not of it, why didst thou, before thou heardest from Me, the case of the sinful woman, hastily blame?  Now this was done for our instruction, that we might be swift to enquire, but slow to pass our sentence.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:535
verses.text: For had that Pharisee been long-suffering, lo! that pardon which our Lord in the end gave to the sinful woman, would have taught him everything.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:536
verses.text: Long-suffering is wont to acquire all things for those that acquire it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:538
verses.text: But again; through the forgiveness of the two debtors, our Lord led into forgiveness him who was in need of forgiveness, yet in whose eyes the forgiveness of debts was hateful.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:539
verses.text: For though the debts of the Pharisee himself needed forgiveness, yet the forgiveness of the debts of the sinful woman was hateful in his eyes.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:540
verses.text: For had there been this forgiveness of debts in the mind of the Pharisee, it would not have been in his eyes disgraceful that that sinful woman should have come for forgiveness of her debts to God and not to the priests; for the priests could not forgive sins such as those.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:541
verses.text: But this sinful woman from the glorious works which our Lord did, believed that He could also forgive sins.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:542
verses.text: For she knew that whoso is able to restore the members of the body, is able also to cleanse away the spots of the soul.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:543
verses.text: But the Pharisee, though he was a teacher, did not know this.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:544
verses.text: For the teachers of Israel were wont to be fools, put to shame by the despised and vile.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:545
verses.text: For they were put to shame by that blind man to whom they said;—We know that this man is a sinner.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:546
verses.text: But he said to them:—How did He open my eyes? lo! God hears not sinners.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:547
verses.text: These are the blind teachers who were made guides to others; and their perverse path was made straight by a blind man.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:549
verses.text: But hear ye the marvel that our Lord wrought.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:550
verses.text: Because that Pharisee supposed that our Lord did not know that the woman who touched Him was a sinner; our Lord made the lips of the Pharisee like the strings of a harp; and by his very lips He sang how she was trampling under foot his sins, though he knew it not.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:551
verses.text: And he who as though he knew had blamed, was found to be a harp, whereto another could sing of that which he knew.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:552
verses.text: For our Lord compared the sins of the sinful woman to five hundred dinars, and caused them to pass into the hearing of the Pharisee by the parable which he heard; and again brought them forth from his mouth in the judgment he gave; though Simon knew not, when he was judging, that those five hundred dinars denoted the sins of the sinful woman.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:553
verses.text: And (the Pharisee) who thought concerning our Lord that He had not knowledge of her sins, was himself found not to have knowledge of them, when he heard of those debts in the parable, and gave judgment concerning them with his voice.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:554
verses.text: But when it was explained to him at last by our Lord, then the Pharisee knew that alike his ears and also his lips were, as it were, instruments for our Lord, through which He might sing the glories of His knowledge.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:555
verses.text: For this Pharisee was the fellow of those scribes, whose sentence by their own mouths our Lord gave against them;—What then will the Lord of the vineyard do to those husbandmen?  They say unto Him, against themselves:—He will terribly destroy them, and will hire out the vineyard to husbandmen who will render unto Him the fruit in its season.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:556
verses.text: This is the Godhead to which all things are easy, which by the mouths, the very mouths that blasphemed it, pronounced the sentence of those very mouths against them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:558
verses.text: Glory then be to Him the Invisible, who clothed Himself in invisibility, that sinners might he able to draw near to Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:559
verses.text: For our Lord did not repel the sinful woman as the Pharisee expected; inasmuch as He descended from the height which no man can reach unto, altogether in order that lowly publicans, like Zaccheus, might reach unto Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:560
verses.text: And the Nature which none can handle, clothed Itself in a body, altogether in order that all lips might kiss His feet as the sinful woman did.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:561
verses.text: For the sacred soul was hidden within the veil of flesh, and so touched all unclean lips and sanctified them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:562
verses.text: Thus He Whom His appetite was supposed to invite to feasting, His feet invited to tears; He was the good Physician, who came forth to go to the sinful woman who was seeking Him in her soul.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:563
verses.text: She then anointed the feet of our Lord, who (anointed) not His head,—she who was trodden down in the dust by all.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:564
verses.text: For those Pharisees who justified themselves and despised all (else), trod her down.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:565
verses.text: But He the Merciful, Whose pure body sanctified her uncleanness, had pity on her.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:567
verses.text: But Mary anointed the head of our Lord's body, as a token of the better part which she had chosen.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:568
verses.text: And Christ prophesied concerning that which her soul had chosen.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:569
verses.text: While Martha was cumbered with serving, Mary was hungering to be satisfied with spiritual things by Him Who also satisfies us with bodily things.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:570
verses.text: So Mary refreshed Him with precious ointment, as He had refreshed her with His exalted teaching.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:571
verses.text: Mary by the oil showed forth the mystery of His mortality, Who by His teaching mortified the concupiscence of her flesh.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:572
verses.text: Thus the sinful woman by the flood of her tears, in full assurance was rewarded with remission of sins from beside His feet; and she who had the issue of blood, stole healing from the hem of His garment.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:573
verses.text: But Mary received blessing openly from His mouth, as a reward of the service of her hands upon His head.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:574
verses.text: For she poured out on His head the precious ointment, and received from His mouth a wonderful promise.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:575
verses.text: This is the ointment which was sown above and yielded fruit below.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:576
verses.text: For she sowed it on His head and gathered its fruit from between His lips;—She shall have a name and this memorial in every place where My Gospel shall be preached.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:577
verses.text: Accordingly, what she then received of Him, He is able to cause to pass unto all generations:  and in no generation can any hinder it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:578
verses.text: For the ointment which she poured upon His head, gave its odour in presence of all the guests and refreshed Him; so also the goodly name which He gave her, passes down through all generations and brings honour to her.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:579
verses.text: Even as all who were at the feast were sensible of her ointment; it was meet that all who come into the world should be sensible of her triumph.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:580
verses.text: This is a loan whereof the increase is exacted in all generations.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:582
verses.text: Now Simeon the priest, when he took Him up in his arms to present Him before God, understood as he saw [Him] that He was not presenting Him, but was being himself presented.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:583
verses.text: For the Son was not presented by the servant to His Father, but the servant was presented by the Son to his Lord.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:584
verses.text: For it is not possible that He, by Whom every offering is presented, should be presented by another.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:585
verses.text: For the offering does not present him that offers it; but by them that offer are offerings presented.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:586
verses.text: So then He Who receives offerings gave Himself to be offered by another, that those who presented Him, while offering Him, might themselves be presented by Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:587
verses.text: For as He gave His body to be eaten, that when eaten It might quicken to life them that ate Him; so He gave Himself to be offered, that by His Cross the hands of them that offered Him might be sanctified.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:588
verses.text: So, then, though the arms of Simeon seemed to be presenting the Son, yet the words of Simeon testified that he was presented by the Son.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:589
verses.text: Therefore we can have no dispute concerning this, because that which was said put an end to dispute;—Now lettest Thou Thy servant depart in peace.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:590
verses.text: He then who is let depart to go in peace to God, is presented as an offering to God.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:591
verses.text: And in order to make known by whom he was presented, he said,—For lo! mine eyes have seen Thy mercy.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:592
verses.text: If there was no grace wrought on him, why then did he give thanks?  But rightly did he give thanks, that he was thought worthy to receive in his arms Him, Whom angels and prophets greatly desired to see.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:593
verses.text: For lo! mine eyes have seen Thy mercy.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:594
verses.text: Let us understand then and see.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:595
verses.text: Is mercy that which shows mercy to another, or is it that which receives mercy from another?  But if mercy is that which shows mercy to all, well did Simeon call our Lord by the name of the mercy that showed mercy to him,—Him Who freed him from the world which is full of snares, that he might go to Eden which is full of pleasures; for he who was priest said and testified that he was offered as an offering, that from the midst of the perishing world he should go and be stored up in the treasure-house which is kept safe.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:596
verses.text: For one for whom it may be that what he has found should be lost, to him it belongs to be diligent that it should be kept safe.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:597
verses.text: But for our Lord it could not be that He should be lost; but by Him the lost were found.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:598
verses.text: So then, through the Son Who could not be lost, the servant who was very desirous not to be lost, was presented.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:599
verses.text: Lo! mine eyes have seen Thy mercy.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:600
verses.text: It is evident Simeon received grace from that Child Whom he was carrying.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:601
verses.text: For inwardly he received grace from that Infant, Whom openly he received in his arms.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:602
verses.text: For through Him Who was glorious, even when He was carried, being small and feeble, he that carried Him was made great.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:604
verses.text: But inasmuch as Simeon endured to carry on his weak arms that Majesty which the creatures could not endure, it is evident that his weakness was made strong by the strength which he carried.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:605
verses.text: For at that time Simeon also along with all creatures was secretly upheld by the almighty strength of the Son.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:606
verses.text: Now this is a marvel, that outwardly it was he that was strengthened that carried Him Who strengthened him; but inwardly it was the strength that bore its bearer.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:607
verses.text: For the Majesty straitened itself, that they who carried it might endure it; in order that as far as that Majesty stooped to our littleness, so far should our love be raised up from all desires to reach that Majesty.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:609
verses.text: So likewise the ship that carried our Lord; it was He that bare it, in that He stayed from it the wind that would have sunk it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:610
verses.text: Peace, for thou art shut up.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:611
verses.text: While He was on the sea, His arm reached even to the fountain of the wind, to shut it up.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:612
verses.text: The ship bare His manhood, but the power of His Godhead bare the ship and all that was therein.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:613
verses.text: But that He might show that even His manhood needed not the ship, instead of the planks which a shipwright puts together and fastens, He like the Architect of creation, made the waters solid and joined them together and laid them under His feet.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:614
verses.text: So the Lord strengthened the hands of Simeon the Priest, that his arms might bear up in the Temple the strength that was bearing up all; as He strengthened the feet of Simeon the Apostle, that they might bear themselves up on the water.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:615
verses.text: And so that name which bore the first-begotten in the Temple was afterwards borne up by the first-begotten in the sea; that He might show that as in the sea the drowning was borne up by Him, He did not need to be borne by Simeon on the dry ground.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:616
verses.text: But our Lord bare Simeon up openly in the midst of the sea to teach that also on the dry land He supported him secretly.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:618
verses.text: Accordingly, the Son came to the servant; not that the Son might be presented by the servant, but that by the Son the servant might present to His Lord Priesthood and Prophecy, to be laid up with Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:619
verses.text: For prophecy and priesthood, which were given through Moses, were handed down, both of them, and reached to Simeon.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:620
verses.text: For he was a pure vessel, who sanctified himself that he might be like Moses, capable for both of them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:621
verses.text: There are small vessels which are capable for great gifts.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:622
verses.text: There are gifts for which one is capable, by reason of their grace; yet many are not capable for them, by reason of their greatness.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:623
verses.text: Thus, then, Simeon presented our Lord, and in Him offered both these things; so that that which was given to Moses in the wilderness, was received from Simeon in the Temple.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:624
verses.text: But seeing that our Lord is the vessel wherein all fulness dwells, when Simeon was offering Him before God, he poured over Him (as a drink-offering) those two (gifts), priesthood from His hands and prophecy from His lips.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:625
verses.text: Priesthood continued on the hands of Simeon, because of his purifications; and prophecy dwelt in operation upon his lips, because of revelations.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:626
verses.text: When then these two powers saw Him who was Lord of both, they two united together and poured themselves into the vessel that was capable of both; that could contain priesthood and kingdom and prophecy.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:627
verses.text: That Infant then, who was wrapped in swaddling clothes, because of His graciousness, clothed Himself in priesthood and prophecy because of His Majesty.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:628
verses.text: For Simeon clothed Him in these, and gave Him to her who had wrapped Him in swaddling clothes.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:629
verses.text: For when he gave Him to His mother, he gave along with Him the priesthood; and when he prophesied to her concerning Him, This (child) is set for the fall and rising again, he gave prophecy also with Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:631
verses.text: Then Mary received her firstborn and went forth.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:632
verses.text: He was outwardly wrapped in swaddling clothes, but secretly He was clothed with prophecy and priesthood.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:633
verses.text: Whatsoever then was handed down from Moses, was received from Simeon, but continued and was possessed by the Lord of both.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:634
verses.text: So then the steward first, and the treasurer lastly, handed over the keys of priesthood and prophecy to Him who has authority over the treasurer of them both.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:635
verses.text: Therefore, His Father gave Him the spirit not by measure, because all measures of the spirit are under his hand.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:636
verses.text: And that our Lord might show that He received the keys from the former stewards, He said to Simeon:  To thee I will give the keys of the doors.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:637
verses.text: But how should He have given them to another, had He not received them from another?  So, then, the keys which He had received from Simeon the priest, them He gave to another Simeon the Apostle; that even though the People had not hearkened to the former Simeon, the Gentiles might hearken to the latter Simeon.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:639
verses.text: But because John also was the treasurer of baptism, the Lord of the stewardship came to him to receive from him the keys of the house of reconciliation.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:640
verses.text: For John used to wash away in common water the blemishes of sins; that bodies might become meet for the garment of the Spirit, given by our Lord.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:641
verses.text: Therefore, because the Spirit was with the Son, He came to John to receive from him baptism, that He might mingle with the visible waters the invisible Spirit; that they whose bodies should feel the moistening of the water, their souls should feel the gift of the Spirit; that even as the bodies outwardly feel the pouring of the water upon them, so the souls inwardly may feel the pouring of the Spirit upon them.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:642
verses.text: Accordingly, even us our Lord when He was baptised, was clothed in baptism and carried baptism with Him, so also when He was presented in the Temple, He put on prophecy and priesthood, and went forth bearing the purity of the priesthood upon His pure members, and bearing the words of prophecy in His wondrous ears.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:643
verses.text: For when Simeon was sanctifying the body of the Child who sanctifies all, that body received the priesthood in its sanctification.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:644
verses.text: And again, when Simeon was prophesying over Him, prophecy quickly entered the hearing of the Child.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:645
verses.text: For if John leaped in the womb and perceived the voice of the Mother of our Lord, how much more should our Lord have heard in the Temple?  For lo! it was because of Him that John knew (so as) to hear in the womb.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:647
verses.text: Accordingly, each one of the gifts that was stored up for the Son, He gathered from their true tree.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:648
verses.text: For He received baptism from the Jordan, even though John still after Him used to baptise.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:649
verses.text: And He received priesthood from the Temple, even though Annas the High Priest exercised it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:650
verses.text: And again, He received prophecy which had been handed down amongst the righteous, even though by it Caiaphas in mockery platted a crown for our Lord, and He received the kingdom from the house of David, even though Herod held the place and exercised it.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:652
verses.text: This is He Who flew and came down from on high; and when all those gifts which He had given to those of old time saw Him, they came flying from every quarter and rested on Him their Giver.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:653
verses.text: For they gathered themselves together from every side, to come and be grafted into their natural tree.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:654
verses.text: For they had been grafted into bitter trees, namely into wicked kings and priests.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:655
verses.text: Therefore they hastened to come to their sweet parent-stock; namely to the Godhead Who in sufficiency came down to the people of Israel, that the parts of Him might be gathered to Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:656
verses.text: And when He received of them that which was His own, that which was not His own was rejected; since for the sake of His own He had borne also with that which was not His own.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:657
verses.text: For He bore with the idolatry of Israel, for the sake of His priesthood; and He bore with its diviners, for the sake of His prophets; and He bore with its wicked dominion, for the sake of His holy crown.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:659
verses.text: But when our Lord took to Himself Priesthood from them, He sanctified by it all the Gentiles.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:660
verses.text: And again, when He took to Himself prophecy, He revealed by it His counsels to all nations.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:661
verses.text: And when he wove His crown, He bound the strong One who takes all men captive, and divides his spoils.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:662
verses.text: These gifts were barren, with the fig-tree, which while it was barren of fruit made barren such glorious powers as these.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:663
verses.text: Therefore as being without fruit, it was cut off, that these gifts might pass forth from it and bring forth fruit abundantly among all the Gentiles.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:665
verses.text: So He, Who came to make our bodies abodes for His indwelling, passed by all those dwelling-places.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:666
verses.text: Let each one of us then be a dwelling-place for Him Who loves me.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:667
verses.text: Let us come to Him and make our abode with Him.

verses.name: On Our Lord 1:668
verses.text: This is the Godhead Whom though all creation cannot contain, yet a lowly and humble soul suffices to receive Him.
